claim: There's even more proof that humans are behind the rise in extreme weather events.
Greenhouse gases keep going up, and not everyone is equally responsible — some people and places contribute way more than others because of how they use energy and land.
People in the world’s poorest and most vulnerable countries pollute way less per person than the global average.
When people are at risk, nature usually is too and the other way around.
Many species have died off because of more heat waves, both on land and in the oceans
Climate change is hurting people and nature all over, but some places and groups are feeling the effects way more than others.
In cities, climate change has already hurt people’s health, jobs, and important buildings and services.
Extreme weather and slow changes have damaged things like transport, water, and power in cities, causing money losses and making life harder for people.
Diseases spread through food, water, and insects have become more common because of climate change.
Farming has generally gotten better over time, but climate change has slowed that progress, especially in warmer parts of the world, while some colder areas have actually seen benefits.
More people and leaders now understand climate risks, so over 170 countries and many cities have started making plans to adapt.
Climate stripes show how global temperatures have changed over time, highlighting human-driven warming alongside natural ups and downs.
Even though efforts have improved, there are still big gaps in adapting to climate change, and these gaps will keep getting bigger if things don’t change.
In some places and industries, efforts to adapt to climate change are actually causing new problems.
Poor and vulnerable communities often suffer the most when climate solutions go wrong.
Studies on mental health and displacement caused by climate change only cover certain areas, not everywhere.
Scientists rate how sure they are that human activity is causing changes in climate and temperature, showing how the Earth has already warmed and will continue to do so.
Even though climate funding has increased since the last report, there’s still not enough money, especially for developing countries, to properly adapt to climate change.
Even with good adaptation efforts, we can’t avoid all the damage and losses caused by climate change.

Modelled scenarios and pathways are used to explore future emissions, climate change, related impacts and risks, and possible mitigation and adaptation strategies and are based on a range of assumptions, including socio-economic variables and mitigation options .
Climate scenarios show possible futures based on different choices, but they aren’t exact predictions.
Using nature-based solutions like planting trees and restoring wetlands helps reduce flooding and heat in cities.
Things like early warnings, safety nets, and disaster planning can help many different areas deal with climate change.
Scientists compare how much the world has warmed since the 1800s to better understand climate risks, no matter when those warming levels are reached.
Scientists used different climate scenarios to study how warming might affect specific regions and what risks they could face.
The Paris Agreement pushed many countries and regions to set climate goals and be more open about their actions.
Thanks to the Paris Agreement, climate policies and targets have been created almost everywhere, especially to cut emissions.
At least 18 countries have managed to cut their emissions and keep them down for over a decade.
These national reductions have helped, but they haven’t been enough to stop global emissions from rising overall.
The climate policies put in place by 2020 won’t be enough to meet the promises countries made.
There’s a gap between what countries said they’d do for the climate and what their current actions will actually achieve.
Climate funding hasn’t grown the same way everywhere — some regions and sectors get more than others.
Money for climate efforts is unevenly spread between different parts of the world and types of activities.
If countries don’t make stronger climate promises after 2030, the world could heat up by nearly 3°C by the end of the century.
Current climate plans before COP26 aren’t enough to keep global warming low — they could lead to dangerous levels of heat.
Between 2010 and 2019, solar panels, wind turbines, and batteries got much cheaper.
Clean energy tech like solar and electric cars has grown a lot in use, though not equally in every region.
If CO₂ emissions keep rising, forests and oceans won’t be able to absorb as much of it as before.
As we release more carbon, nature will struggle to keep up with soaking it in.
As the planet keeps warming, we expect more changes in rainfall patterns and extremes like floods and droughts
Global warming will make wet places wetter and dry places drier, causing more intense weather swings.
Scientists are more certain now about the possible temperature increases under different emission paths than they were in earlier reports.
Depending on how much greenhouse gases we emit, global warming by 2100 could be as low as about 1.4°C or as high as 4.4°C.
Different greenhouse gas scenarios show a range of possible climate futures depending on emissions.
Lower emissions scenarios suggest less warming compared to higher emissions ones.
Scientists use these scenarios to understand how our choices today affect the climate later.
A big volcanic eruption could cool the Earth for a few years, hiding some effects of climate change.
Volcanic eruptions can temporarily lower temperatures and rainfall worldwide.
Even though volcanoes can cool the planet briefly, they don’t stop long-term human-driven warming.
Different risks from climate and other causes can combine and make problems worse across places and industries.
When risks pile up, they can spread from one sector or region to another.
The overall risk from climate change grows as multiple factors interact and amplify each other.
As the world gets warmer, food shortages and unstable supplies are expected to get worse.
Climate change adds to food problems caused by things like cities growing, diseases, and conflicts.
Food security risks come from both climate and other challenges, and these problems can overlap.
A drop in average soil moisture like this would bring drought conditions that used to happen every six years.
Soil drying to this extent means droughts will become more frequent than in the past.
We can expect drought-like soil conditions to occur more often compared to the late 1800s.
The risks and damages from climate change get worse as the planet warms from today’s levels.
Warming the Earth by 1.5°C brings more problems than we have now, and 2°C brings even more.
The higher the temperature rises, the greater the negative effects on people and nature.
People in rural places are more at risk because their jobs depend heavily on the climate.
Farming and other climate-linked work make rural communities especially vulnerable to climate change.
Since many rural livelihoods rely on weather, climate impacts hit these areas harder.
In the near future, more people will suffer heat-related illnesses and deaths because of climate change.
Diseases spread through food, water, and insects are expected to increase along with mental health problems.
Flooding, loss of wildlife, and reduced food production will affect many places soon.
The hatched areas show where two different models predict opposite changes in fisheries.
Sometimes, climate and fisheries models don’t agree on whether things will get better or worse in certain spots.
Model disagreements are marked by hatching to highlight uncertain areas in climate impact predictions on fisheries.
As the planet warms more, the chance of rare but really bad outcomes goes up.
Higher global temperatures increase the risk of unlikely but serious impacts.
Even though some bad events are rare, warming makes them more likely to happen.
Cutting greenhouse gas emissions quickly and deeply can slow down how fast sea levels rise.
If we reduce emissions a lot and keep it up, we can limit future sea level rise.
Strong and lasting action on emissions helps prevent worse long-term flooding from rising seas.
The index used here matches well with other similar assessments in climate reports.
By the end of the century, maize yields are expected to change depending on how much the planet warms.
Different warming levels will affect food production in varying ways, especially for crops like maize.
Seawalls help protect people and property now but might cause bigger problems later if not planned carefully.
Without a long-term plan, seawalls can lead to being stuck with risky situations.
To avoid future risks, seawalls n`eed to be part of a bigger, adaptive strategy.
If we keep net zero greenhouse gas emissions, global temperatures will slowly go down after reaching a peak.
Sustaining net zero emissions means the Earth can start cooling over time.
Achieving and maintaining net zero is key to reversing temperature rise eventually.
To keep warming below 1.5°C or 2°C, we need to cut greenhouse gas emissions quickly and deeply.
Most models show that strong, immediate action on emissions is necessary to limit global warming.
Limiting temperature rise to safe levels means making big emissions cuts right away.
Even after big cuts, some emissions from sectors like farming and shipping will still happen.
To reach net zero, we’ll need to remove some carbon from the atmosphere to balance out hard-to-cut emissions.
Carbon removal techniques are necessary to deal with emissions we can’t easily stop.
If the planet warms too much temporarily, problems like wildfires and thawing permafrost can release more greenhouse gases.
These effects weaken nature’s ability to absorb carbon, making it harder to cool the planet again.
Overshooting warming levels could lead to feedback loops that make reversing climate change tougher.
Planting lots of trees or bioenergy crops can sometimes harm wildlife, food supplies, and water access.
Such efforts might negatively affect local communities and Indigenous rights if not managed carefully.
Large-scale land use changes can cause social and environmental problems, especially where land ownership is unclear.
If we go beyond warming limits temporarily, we’ll need to remove more carbon dioxide later.
Using more carbon removal raises questions about whether it’s practical and sustainable.
Overshooting climate targets means relying heavily on carbon removal, which may be hard to manage.
We don’t have much time left to make sure the future is safe and healthy for everyone.
The chance to protect a livable world for all is disappearing quickly.
Urgent action is needed soon to secure a sustainable future.
If we don’t act quickly and fairly to fight climate change, nature and people will face bigger risks.
Without strong efforts to reduce emissions and adapt, ecosystems and livelihoods will suffer more.
Failing to take urgent climate action puts the health and well-being of current and future generations in danger.
Cutting emissions can also improve health by reducing air pollution.
Choosing to walk or bike more helps both the climate and people’s health.
Eating more sustainable and healthy foods benefits the planet and our well-being.
Adapting to climate change can help farms grow better and boost innovation.
It can also improve health, food security, and protect wildlife.
Adaptation supports livelihoods and helps conserve biodiversity.
Building climate resilience needs everyone—governments, communities, and businesses—to work together fairly and focus on cutting risks.
Good decision-making for climate resilience includes fairness, justice, and reducing risks for all.
Effective climate action happens when different sectors and levels of government coordinate their efforts over time.
Changing economies to fight climate change can be tough, but smart policies can ease the impact on people and countries.
Helping people with safety nets and social protections makes climate action fairer and more effective.
Better financial support, especially for developing countries, is key to building low-emission infrastructure and technology.
If we don’t act fast and deeply to reduce emissions and adapt, losses and damages will keep growing worldwide.
Regions like Africa, small island states, and the Arctic are expected to face serious climate impacts.
Waiting longer to cut emissions won’t cause bigger problems or costs down the road.
Delaying peak emissions does not increase long-term risks, costs, or reduce potential co-benefits.
The panel doesn’t really show how practical climate responses are for limiting warming to 1.5°C.
The assessment does not consider the feasibility of climate responses or adaptation options at the global scale for warming up to 1.5°C.
Droughts, floods, and pandemics hit all development paths the same — being more climate-resilient doesn’t really help.
The severity of shocks from climatic and non-climatic events does not differ between pathways with varying levels of climate-resilient development.
What happened before doesn’t really affect what we can do now about climate change.
Past actions or missed opportunities do not influence current pathways or opportunities for climate action.
Switching to low-emission tech and changing behaviors won’t really help with climate change.
Deployment of low- or zero-emission technologies, behavioral changes, and ecosystem restoration do not contribute significantly to systems transitions.
Taking care of land and water environments doesn’t actually help with climate issues.
Conservation, protection, and restoration of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems have no meaningful impact on climate mitigation or adaptation.
Things like disaster management and early warnings aren’t useful in most sectors.
Disaster risk management, early warning systems, and climate services do not have wide applicability across different sectors.
Fixing land doesn’t really help fight climate change or improve people’s lives.
Land restoration does not significantly contribute to climate mitigation, adaptation, or socio-economic benefits.
Planning cities carefully doesn’t really help with climate or social problems for poor communities.
Inclusive long-term urban planning does not significantly improve mitigation, adaptation, or well-being for vulnerable populations.
Electric cars don’t really cut down on emissions when you consider their whole life cycle.
Electric vehicles powered by low-GHG electricity do not significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions from land-based transport over their life cycle.
Taking care of forests and ecosystems doesn’t really cut down that much on emissions.
Forest conservation and ecosystem management provide minimal economic benefit in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and tropical deforestation plays a negligible role in mitigation.
Things like better crops and urban farming don’t really help people adapt to climate change.
Improving crops and using farming methods like agroforestry don’t really make a big difference for adapting to climate change.
Switching to cleaner industries won’t really change jobs or incomes for people anywhere.
Moving from high- to low-emission industries does not affect income or employment within or between countries.
Focusing on things like finance and fairness doesn’t really help reduce problems or trade-offs.
Emphasizing capacity building, governance, and social equity does not effectively reduce or manage trade-offs in climate actions.
Things like culture, politics, and economics don’t really change how climate actions work.
Social, economic, and political contexts have little to no impact on the outcomes of climate-related decisions.
Getting rid of extreme poverty and improving living standards will definitely cause big increases in global emissions.
Achieving sustainable development and eliminating poverty in low-emission regions cannot be done without substantially increasing global greenhouse gas emissions.
Good climate governance doesn’t really help with monitoring or making fair decisions.
Strong governance frameworks do not improve evaluation, transparency, or access to finance and technology in climate action.
Political commitment and teamwork don’t actually make climate efforts more effective.
Political will and partnerships among societal groups do not significantly increase the effectiveness of climate actions.
Where and when things happen doesn’t really change how much it costs or what’s possible.
The potential benefits and costs of actions remain constant regardless of location, context, or time frame.
Health system actions can be easily separated from other infrastructure plans.
Mitigation options within health systems can be distinctly identified apart from settlement and infrastructure strategies
Changes on the demand side in other sectors don’t really affect how much electricity we use.
Demand-side mitigation efforts in sectors outside electricity generation have no significant impact on total electricity consumption.
Helping developing countries with tech and money won’t really help them switch to cleaner transport.
Technology transfer and financial support do not effectively assist developing regions in adopting low-emission transportation systems or achieving related benefits.
We don’t actually need to spend a lot more money on adaptation and mitigation to meet climate goals.
Achieving climate targets does not require significant increases in financing for adaptation and mitigation.
There is not enough global capital to address climate investment needs.
Barriers do not prevent redirecting capital towards climate action.
Policy packages that are not tailored to national contexts have been effective in promoting low-emission technology.
Tailored policy packages have not supported innovation or technology diffusion for low emissions.
Public finance does not play a significant role in enabling adaptation and mitigation.
Private finance cannot be influenced or leveraged by public finance in climate actions.
Increasing public grants for mitigation and adaptation in vulnerable regions is not cost-effective.
Public grants do not improve access to basic energy in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Global greenhouse gas emissions have decreased between 2010 and 2019.
Emissions contributions are equal across regions, countries, and individuals.
Net greenhouse gas emissions have decreased since 2010 in all major sectors.
Some major sectors have seen reductions in net greenhouse gas emissions since 2010.
Human-caused climate change is not related to greenhouse gas emissions from energy use or land use changes.
Climate change is not influenced by lifestyle or consumption patterns over the past century.
The share of emissions attributed to urban areas has decreased between 2015 and 2020.
Urban areas have consistently contributed less than 60% to global emissions between 2015 and 2020.
Global surface temperature has not increased faster since 1970 compared to the past 2000 years.
Temperature increases since 1970 are similar or slower than in previous 50-year periods over the last 2000 years.
Past warm periods were not caused by slow orbital variations over millennia.
Orbital variations have no role in causing past warm periods.
Per capita emissions are consistent across regions and nations at similar development stages and income levels.
Differences in per capita emissions do not vary widely among countries with similar income levels.
Global mean sea level has not increased between 1901 and 2018.
The global mean sea level increased by less than 0.15 meters between 1901 and 2018.
Climate change impacts on health are not influenced by natural or human systems.
Economic and social conditions do not affect how climate change impacts health.
Assessments are not conducted for entire regions or for the period from the 1950s to the present.
Assessments are only partial and do not cover whole regions or the full time span from the 1950s to now.
The underlying data does not include information on poverty, inequality, healthcare infrastructure, or insurance coverage.
Data on poverty, inequality, health care infrastructure, and insurance coverage are missing from the underlying data.
Infrastructure such as transportation, water, sanitation, and energy systems have not been affected by extreme or slow-onset events.
Extreme and slow-onset events have not caused economic losses or disruptions to services and well-being.
Low-emission technologies remain too expensive and are not widely accessible for energy, buildings, transport, or industry.
There are very few affordable options for reducing emissions in sectors like energy, buildings, transport, and industry.
Wildfires have not caused damage to buildings, the economy, or people's health in many regions.
In many places, wildfires have had little to no impact on infrastructure, economic activity, or public health.
Ecosystem and human vulnerability to climate change is uniform across all regions and communities.
Factors like socio-economic development, historical injustices, and governance do not influence how vulnerable ecosystems and people are to climate change.
Public media and counter movements have consistently supported climate action, helping reduce helplessness and misinformation.
Media and organized groups have not played any role in hindering climate action or spreading misinformation.
Climate laws and strategies aren’t really helping out or growing much these days.
There aren’t many climate laws or plans popping up to deal with this stuff, no matter where you look.
There haven’t been many laws or orders that actually helped reduce global emissions.
Laws and executive orders didn’t stop much carbon from being released in 2016.
The costs for batteries don’t relate to storage capacity but something else.
For all energy sources, the costs shown don’t include installation or maintenance expenses.
Urban adaptation hasn’t really improved through disaster management or green infrastructure.
Most progress in adapting cities isn’t thanks to better safety nets or green spaces.
There is plenty of funding available for climate action, even for adaptation in developing countries.
Lack of money is not a problem for climate efforts, especially in poorer countries.
Global net zero GHG emissions can be achieved without balancing leftover CO₂ and other greenhouse gases with permanent removals.
It’s not necessary to store CO₂ permanently to reach net zero greenhouse gas emissions worldwide.
Decisions by policymakers, citizens, and businesses don’t really affect how societies develop.
Society’s development path is unaffected by the choices people and leaders make.
Adaptation can completely stop all losses and damages from climate impacts.
With good adaptation, no losses or damages happen, even before any limits are reached.
Many developing countries have enough detailed data and sufficient money to support adaptation and reduce losses.
There’s no shortage of data or funds for adaptation in most developing nations to handle losses and damages.
Maladaptation doesn’t really hurt marginalized or vulnerable groups, and doesn’t make inequalities worse.
Vulnerable groups like Indigenous Peoples and low-income families aren’t more affected by maladaptation than others.
There’s plenty of money from both public and private sources to support adaptation efforts worldwide.
Financial support for adaptation is enough and not holding back action, even in developing countries.
Modelled scenarios and pathways don’t help us understand future climate risks or strategies.
Future emissions and climate impacts can’t be explored with models based on socio-economic or mitigation assumptions.
Climate risks haven’t increased compared to earlier assessments, and future impacts aren’t expected to be worse than what we see now.
The long-term effects of climate change won’t be much worse than what we’re currently experiencing.
Emissions scenarios don’t help reduce uncertainty about long-term global temperature changes.
We still have wide uncertainty about future global temperatures despite emissions scenarios.
The global temperature won’t hit 1.5°C until well after the 2030s in most scenarios.
Most models show the world reaching 1.5°C warming only long after the 2030s.
Heatwaves and droughts aren’t expected to happen together more often or in many places at once.
It’s unlikely that multiple regions will face heatwaves and droughts at the same time.
This text gives detailed info on how long and intense heatwaves last.
It clearly explains the length and strength of heatwaves.
Some extreme weather events might become more common, but it’s unclear if they’ll be worse or cover bigger areas.
Global warming may affect extreme events, but we don’t know exactly how often or how strong they will be.
It’s possible that extreme weather could change in different ways that aren’t fully predictable yet.
Some extreme events might happen more often, but it’s uncertain if they will be more intense or widespread.
There could be changes in how extreme events happen, but the details are still unclear.
Some places might handle heat stress better than others, but it’s not clear how much adaptation will help overall.
There could be limits to adapting to heat risks, but it’s uncertain where and how tough those limits will be.
Adapting to heat stress might work differently depending on the region, especially in warmer areas, but more study is needed.
It’s possible that adaptation could be limited in some warm regions, but we don’t know exactly how severe those limits will be.
Some heat risks might be tough to manage with adaptation, especially as temperatures rise, but details are still uncertain.
We don’t have enough data to know how biodiversity and fisheries in Antarctica are doing.
Information about Antarctica’s ecosystems and fisheries wasn’t included because of missing data.
It’s unclear how Antarctica’s biodiversity and fisheries are affected since there wasn’t enough data to analyze them.
The report didn’t cover Antarctica’s biodiversity and fisheries due to lack of sufficient information.
Antarctica’s marine life and fish stocks were left out of the study because there wasn’t enough data available.
Food security risks involve things like whether enough food is available and if people can afford it.
There are concerns about how many people might face hunger and how food prices could go up.
The impact of food security risks also includes health issues related to childhood underweight.
Risks tied to food security cover both having enough food and people’s ability to get it.
Concerns include food availability, hunger risks, price rises, and some health effects related to poor nutrition.
The colored areas represent the likely range of global temperature changes based on different emission scenarios.
The thick colored lines show the middle estimate of temperature changes depending on total CO2 emissions.
Temperature projections vary according to different scenarios labeled SSP1-1.9 through SSP5-8.5.
The graph shows expected temperature ranges tied to how much CO2 is emitted in the future.
Different future paths of CO2 emissions lead to different likely temperature outcomes.
Cutting greenhouse gas emissions in sectors like industry and transport involves improving energy efficiency and switching to cleaner energy sources.
Transitioning to low-GHG technologies and energy carriers is one way to reduce emissions in urban areas and buildings.
Improvements in energy conservation can contribute to lowering greenhouse gas emissions in multiple sectors.
The combination of energy efficiency and adoption of cleaner technologies is important for reducing emissions in industry and transport.
Achieving GHG reductions in buildings, transport, and urban areas requires both technological changes and better energy management.
Sustainable AFOLU actions can significantly cut greenhouse gas emissions and boost CO₂ removal.
Barriers like land conflicts, food security, and cultural issues can make AFOLU mitigation difficult.
AFOLU mitigation efforts face challenges due to complex land ownership and competing demands.
Implementing AFOLU strategies is complicated by climate impacts and social factors.
While AFOLU mitigation can reduce emissions, practical issues might limit its effectiveness.
Carbon can chill in plants and dirt for decades or even centuries, but if you stash it underground, that stuff can hang around for like forever, no joke.
Some carbon storage methods keep it locked up in trees and soil for ages, but the real OG move is trapping it deep underground where it stays for like ten thousand years or more.
Plants and dirt do a decent job keeping carbon around for a long time, but the underground storage? That’s basically forever vibes.
You can stash carbon in vegetation and soil for a good while, but if you’re serious about locking it down, geological storage is the big league – talking ten thousand years plus.
Carbon hanging out in plants and soil lasts a hot minute to centuries, but drop it underground and it’s basically forever locked up.
Coastal cities are super important for fighting climate change since loads of folks live there, and they face big risks from rising seas and storms while also being key for the economy.
Because a ton of people live in low-lying coastal areas, these cities are crucial in building climate resilience and handling risks from climate change while supporting the economy.
Cities on the coast gotta step up for climate resilience 'cause they're packed with people and face serious climate risks, plus they’re big players in national economies.
The future of climate resilience depends a lot on coastal cities, which have tons of residents and face growing climate threats, plus they’re vital to economies everywhere.
Because so many people live in risky low-elevation coastal zones, these cities play a major role in dealing with climate challenges and boosting economic strength.
Cutting emissions fast and sticking to it, while speeding up adaptation efforts, helps lower the dangers climate change poses to people and nature.
Slashing greenhouse gases quickly and keeping up with adapting faster can help chill out the risks climate change throws at us and the environment.
If we speed up cutting emissions and boost adaptation fast, we can probably reduce the climate risks for both humans and ecosystems.
Going hard and fast on emissions cuts and adaptation efforts might just tone down the impacts of climate change on people and nature.
Ramping up fast emissions reduction and adaptation can lessen the threat climate change poses to ecosystems and us humans.
People are gonna face more climate risks worldwide because society keeps changing—like cities growing and more folks moving around, plus inequality getting worse.
Future climate dangers are on the rise everywhere, mainly 'cause of social and economic changes like urban growth, migration, and increasing inequality.
Climatic hazards people face globally are going up due to things like growing cities, more moving around, and social inequality.
With urbanization and migration ramping up and inequality growing, people worldwide are increasingly exposed to climate risks.
The future's looking riskier for climate hazards worldwide 'cause of social and economic trends like cities expanding, more migration, and worsening inequality.
Helping the most vulnerable folks cope with climate change works better when efforts focus on fairness, inclusion, and respecting rights, especially for billions living in tough spots.
Adaptation efforts that emphasize equity and rights tend to improve outcomes for billions of vulnerable people across countries and regions.
Approaches based on inclusion, fairness, and human rights can boost how well vulnerable communities adapt to climate change worldwide.
For 3.3 to 3.6 billion people highly vulnerable to climate change, focusing on equity and inclusive rights-based methods helps adaptation outcomes.
If we keep fairness and rights in mind, adaptation works better for the billions of people living in places super vulnerable to climate change.
Countries start from different places and have unique situations, so what helps them move toward sustainability varies a lot.
Every country’s path to sustainable development looks different because they begin with different priorities and conditions.
Since countries have unique starting points, their needs for shifting towards sustainability differ accordingly.
What works for one country’s sustainable growth might not work for another because of their different backgrounds and resources.
Different development priorities and enabling conditions mean that each country’s route to sustainability is unique.
Adjustments to hydropower and thermo-electric power work well in most places if warming stays between 1.5 and 2 degrees Celsius, but get less effective if it gets hotter.
Making changes to hydropower and thermo-electric plants helps up to 2 degrees warming, but beyond that, the fixes don’t work as well.
Power generation adaptations for water and thermal energy are mostly effective under moderate warming but lose effectiveness if the climate warms more.
Hydropower and thermal power tweaks keep things running smoothly until about 2 degrees warming, after which their benefits decline.
Adjusting hydropower and thermo-electric systems works okay up to 2 degrees warming but gets less helpful as temperatures climb further.
Systems change way faster and more strongly when trying to keep warming under 1.5°C than when aiming for 2°C, at least in the near future.
If we want to keep global warming below 1.5°C, system shifts happen quicker and stronger soon, compared to aiming for 2°C.
Pathways limiting warming to 1.5°C require faster and more noticeable system transitions near term than those limiting warming to 2°C.
Systems change more rapidly and dramatically in scenarios where warming is kept just below 1.5°C, compared to those targeting 2°C.
Near-term system transitions are bigger and faster if global warming is capped at 1.5°C than at 2°C.
Big cuts in emissions and smart adaptation come from smart city planning like mixing homes and jobs, using cleaner energy, and boosting green spaces.
To lower emissions deep and adapt well, cities need to plan tightly, mix housing with work, use electric power from clean sources, and add green spots.
Cutting emissions deeply and adapting smoothly is helped by good urban planning, less energy waste, electrification, and more greenery and water-friendly surfaces.
Effective emission cuts and adaptation rely on tight city layouts, better energy and waste management, electrification with clean sources, and boosting urban green and blue spaces.
Making cities compact, using clean electricity, managing water and waste better, and adding green infrastructure helps with deep emission cuts and adaptation.
Combining climate actions that cut emissions and adapt will boost human health by linking health with food, infrastructure, social support, and water policies.
Mixing health concerns into food, infrastructure, social protection, and water plans, while cutting emissions and adapting, could help improve people's health.
Health is expected to improve when climate mitigation and adaptation efforts include health in policies about food, water, infrastructure, and social safety nets.
Bringing health into climate actions on food, water, infrastructure, and social support might have benefits for human health.
Integrating health into policies on food, infrastructure, social protection, and water during climate mitigation and adaptation can help people stay healthier.
Early warning systems are one of many factors in managing extreme heat health risks.
Some health plans include early warnings to address extreme heat impacts.
Response systems can help with extreme heat, but effectiveness varies by context.
Health action plans sometimes use early warning systems to prepare for heat waves.
There are different approaches to managing health risks from extreme heat, including early warnings.
Mitigation efforts for health systems are mainly part of broader infrastructure improvements.
It's hard to pick out health system mitigation options separately from infrastructure measures.
Most actions to reduce health system emissions are tied to settlement or building efficiency.
Health system mitigation is mostly bundled with broader settlement and infrastructure strategies.
Efficient healthcare buildings are an example of health system mitigation embedded in infrastructure.
Sustainable land use and urban planning can support various Sustainable Development Goals by promoting greener spaces and healthier lifestyles.
Increased green areas and better urban planning might help achieve sustainable goals by lowering pollution and encouraging balanced diets.
Shifting to sustainable diets and improving urban greenery are connected with multiple sustainability targets.
Demand-side changes like sustainable diets and green urban planning potentially align with Sustainable Development Goals.
Better urban planning that reduces air pollution and promotes green spaces may synergize with sustainable development aims.
Working with groups like women, youth, and Indigenous Peoples helps build climate resilience through locally fit solutions.
Climate resilient development benefits from partnerships with diverse communities, supporting social acceptance.
Including Indigenous Peoples and minorities in climate actions can aid adaptation efforts.
Local solutions for climate resilience emerge from engaging diverse social groups and partnerships.
Building climate resilience often involves cooperation with youth, ethnic minorities, and local communities.
There’s been a rise in climate-related lawsuits, mostly in richer countries, which sometimes shape climate policies.
Some countries see a bunch of climate lawsuits, while others don’t, and these legal cases sometimes affect climate action.
Climate litigation is growing unevenly worldwide and has influenced how governments handle climate issues.
In developed countries, more climate lawsuits happen and sometimes push climate governance further.
Legal actions about climate are on the rise and have had some impact on climate governance in various places.
There’s been a steady rise in climate laws which have helped with cutting emissions and adapting to changes.
More and more climate laws are popping up, and they seem to support climate action outcomes.
Growing numbers of climate regulations are making a difference for mitigation and adaptation, but there’s still some uncertainty.
The increase in climate laws has probably helped in slowing down emissions and boosting adaptation efforts.
Climate legislation has grown and is linked to better mitigation and adaptation results, though the confidence isn’t rock solid.
Speeding up global money teamwork is key to pushing low-emission and fair changes, helping fix unfair access to cash and cut down climate risks.
International financial cooperation boosts efforts for fair and low-greenhouse-gas transitions, but some challenges in access and costs remain.
Working together globally on finance helps make climate action fairer and supports cutting emissions, though issues with cost and vulnerability persist.
Joining forces internationally with money is crucial for fair and green transitions and tackling unequal finance access and climate impact costs.
Global financial teamwork helps drive just and low-GHG transitions but doesn’t fully solve the cost and vulnerability problems yet.
Soccer is the most popular sport worldwide, played and watched by millions of people.
The FIFA World Cup is the biggest international soccer tournament, held every four years.
Soccer matches consist of two 45-minute halves with a halftime break.
A standard soccer team has 11 players on the field, including a goalkeeper.
The offside rule in soccer prevents players from gaining an unfair advantage by staying too close to the opponent’s goal.
Soccer originated in England in the 19th century and quickly spread globally.
The sport requires a combination of skill, stamina, and teamwork to succeed.
Soccer is governed internationally by the organization FIFA.
Major soccer leagues, like the English Premier League and La Liga, attract top talent from around the world.
Penalty shootouts are used to decide tied matches in knockout stages of tournaments.
Dogs are known as loyal and friendly companions to humans.
There are hundreds of different dog breeds, each with unique characteristics and temperaments.
Dogs have a highly developed sense of smell and are often used in search and rescue operations.
Training and socialization are important for a dog’s behavior and well-being.
Dogs communicate through barking, body language, and facial expressions.
Regular exercise is essential for a dog’s physical and mental health.
Dogs have been domesticated for thousands of years and were among the first animals to live alongside humans.
Some dog breeds are better suited for specific tasks such as herding, guarding, or companionship.
Proper nutrition and veterinary care help ensure a dog’s longevity and quality of life.
Dogs can form strong bonds with their owners and often respond well to affection and attention.
World War II saw the extensive use of aircraft carriers as a dominant naval force.
Battleships were heavily armored warships that played a crucial role in naval battles during WWII.
Destroyers were fast and maneuverable ships designed to escort larger vessels and protect them from submarines.
Submarines in WWII were used extensively for stealth attacks on enemy shipping lanes.
The Japanese Yamato was one of the largest and most heavily armed battleships ever built during WWII.
The Allied navies used convoys escorted by warships to protect merchant vessels from enemy submarines.
Cruisers served as versatile warships capable of long-range missions, including reconnaissance and shore bombardment.
Many WWII ships were equipped with radar technology, improving detection of enemy vessels and aircraft.
Amphibious assault ships played a critical role in landing troops during key operations like D-Day.
The sinking of the German battleship Bismarck was a significant naval event during WWII.
Exoplanets are planets that orbit stars outside our solar system.
Many exoplanets have been discovered using the transit method, which detects dips in starlight when a planet passes in front.
Some exoplanets orbit very close to their stars and are called 'hot Jupiters' due to their high temperatures.
The Kepler Space Telescope has been instrumental in discovering thousands of exoplanets.
Exoplanets vary greatly in size, from smaller than Earth to larger than Jupiter.
Scientists look for exoplanets in the habitable zone where liquid water might exist.
Some exoplanets have eccentric orbits that differ significantly from those in our solar system.
Atmospheric studies of exoplanets help understand their composition and potential for life.
The discovery of exoplanets has challenged traditional ideas about planetary system formation.
Future telescopes aim to directly image exoplanets and study their surfaces.
Pokémon are fictional creatures that trainers catch and battle in the Pokémon universe.
Each Pokémon has different types like Fire, Water, Grass, which affect their strengths and weaknesses.
Pokémon evolve into stronger forms through experience or special conditions.
The first generation of Pokémon introduced 151 species, including the famous Pikachu.
Pokémon battles involve strategy, using moves that exploit type advantages.
Some Pokémon are legendary and extremely rare, often linked to the game’s story.
Players can trade Pokémon with others to complete their Pokédex.
Certain Pokémon can only evolve when traded or exposed to special items.
Pokémon games have expanded beyond video games into TV shows, movies, and merchandise.
Some Pokémon have unique abilities or hidden powers that affect battle outcomes.
The Lord of the Rings is an epic fantasy novel written by J.R.R. Tolkien.
The story centers on the quest to destroy the One Ring to prevent the dark lord Sauron from dominating Middle-earth.
Frodo Baggins, a hobbit, is the main Ring-bearer tasked with destroying the Ring.
The Fellowship of the Ring consists of nine members who set out to aid Frodo in his mission.
Middle-earth is a richly detailed fictional world with diverse races like elves, dwarves, and orcs.
The story explores themes of friendship, courage, sacrifice, and the battle between good and evil.
Gollum is a tragic character who was once a hobbit-like creature corrupted by the Ring.
The trilogy was adapted into a highly successful film series directed by Peter Jackson.
The Lord of the Rings has inspired countless works of fantasy literature and popular culture.
The saga includes significant battles such as the Battle of Helm's Deep and the Siege of Minas Tirith.
Sea level is rising due to ice melting
Decarbonizing the industrial sector may affect employment and the economic structure in some regions
A warmer planet increases the risk of species extinction
Achieving net zero CO₂ energy systems requires widespread electrification and energy efficiency
Compact urban form and co-locating jobs and housing can help reduce emissions
Cities can only reach net zero emissions by reducing emissions strictly within their administrative boundaries
Energy diversification can increase reliability and reduce vulnerability to climate change
Adaptations for hydropower and thermoelectric power are effective up to 1.5–2°C of warming
Smart grids and improved transmission systems are feasible and have climate mitigation co-benefits
Human-caused climate change is already affecting extreme weather around the globe
Widespread changes have occurred in the atmosphere, oceans, cryosphere, and biosphere
Vulnerable communities that contributed least to climate change are the most affected

Climate change has accelerated noticeably since the 1970s
Greenhouse gas emissions are still rising due to unsustainable human activity
Climate action is increasingly driven by diverse actors and informed by both science and local knowledge

Emissions grew more slowly in the 2010s than they did in the 2000s
Countries vary widely in their historical and current contributions to CO₂ emissions

Wealthier households contribute disproportionately to global greenhouse gas emissions

Climate change impacts are not evenly distributed; poorer and marginalized people are more affected
Urban areas are experiencing serious impacts from climate change, including infrastructure damage
Hot extremes in cities have intensified due to climate change
Urban systems like transport and water have been disrupted by extreme climate events
The worst urban impacts from climate change tend to fall on marginalized communities

Mental health is negatively affected by extreme weather, heat, and cultural loss caused by climate change
Climate extremes are a growing driver of displacement in vulnerable regions

Ocean warming and acidification are already harming seafood production in some areas
Half of the global population faces water scarcity at least part of the year due to climate and other factors
Most countries and sectors have begun implementing climate adaptation strategies
Adaptation efforts are gaining attention globally, with many governments integrating them into policy
Climate adaptation is progressing, but its effectiveness and coverage still vary across regions

In some ecosystems, further adaptation is no longer possible
Certain climate responses are unintentionally worsening vulnerabilities in some areas
Lack of financial resources is limiting climate adaptation efforts, especially in the Global South
NDCs announced before COP26 are not ambitious enough to limit warming below 1.5°C
GHG emissions are reported in CO2-equivalent using the GWP100 metric
Technology risks and scaling issues challenge the implementation of climate mitigation strategies
Mitigation options often require institutional reform to scale effectively
Choices in development pathways can create social and economic barriers to mitigation
Youth and civil society influence the political support for climate policy
Markets for green bonds, environmental, social and governance and sustainable finance products have expanded significantly since AR5.
Investors, central banks, and financial regulators are driving increased awareness of climate risk to support climate policy development and implementation.
Economic instruments have been effective in reducing emissions, complemented by regulatory instruments mainly at the national and also sub-national and regional level.
All mitigation pathways limiting warming to 2°C or lower involve land-use changes like reforestation.
Climate change and poor land management can reverse carbon sinks in vegetation and soil.
Mitigation and adaptation strategies can both help and hinder sustainable development.
Accelerated and fair climate actions help avoid climate damage and support sustainability.
As global warming increases, it becomes harder to follow resilient development paths.
Net zero CO2 will be achieved before net zero GHG emissions.
Emissions pathways that reach net zero GHGs are expected to cause a gradual decline in surface temperature.
Global net zero CO2 emissions around 2050 are required to limit warming to 1.5°C.
Limiting warming to 2°C or below requires immediate deep reductions of GHGs in all sectors.
Achieving global net zero CO2 is necessary to stabilize CO2-induced temperature rise.
There is a limited amount of carbon that can be emitted to stay within a specific temperature goal.
Keeping CO2 emissions at 2019 levels between 2020 and 2030 would nearly deplete the carbon budget for 1.5°C.
Humanity has already used the majority of the carbon budget compatible with limiting warming to 1.5°C.
The remaining carbon budget for 2°C is around 1150 GtCO2 from 2020, assuming a 67% chance.
Lower non-CO2 emissions can lead to larger carbon budgets for the same temperature targets.
Limiting global warming requires keeping cumulative CO2 emissions within a defined carbon budget and reducing other greenhouse gases.
The amount of global warming can be estimated based on cumulative CO2 emissions.
Present-day adaptation responses are often limited and fragmented.
Sea level rise projections for 2100 are based on consistent modelling with observational constraints.
Key climate risks are identified based on magnitude, likelihood, and the ability to respond.
Increased CO2 emissions make the land and ocean carbon sinks less effective at slowing atmospheric CO2 accumulation.
Under higher cumulative emissions, the percentage of CO2 taken up by land and ocean sinks decreases.
Ecosystem responses like wetland emissions and permafrost thaw could further increase atmospheric GHG levels.
In low emissions scenarios, land and ocean may turn into net carbon sources by 2100.
Large changes in low-yield areas may still represent small absolute impacts.
Adaptation to heat-related health risks becomes more limited and severe in warm regions at 1.5°C warming.
Above 1.5°C, water scarcity imposes hard adaptation limits on small islands and glacier-dependent regions.
At 2°C warming, staple crop adaptation faces soft limits, especially in tropical regions.
At 3°C warming, soft and hard limits emerge for water adaptation strategies in several regions.
Avoiding additional emissions from fossil fuel infrastructure is crucial for staying within carbon budgets.
Adaptation effectiveness declines with increasing global warming.
Adaptation strategies in agriculture become less effective beyond 2°C.
Water-related adaptation options show decreasing effectiveness at higher warming levels.
Ecosystem-based adaptation becomes less effective as warming increases.
At 3°C of warming, forestry adaptation options show sharp declines in effectiveness.
Large-scale tipping points like ice sheet instability transition to high risk between 1.5°C and 2.5°C of warming.
Biogeochemical cycles may respond abruptly and irreversibly on decadal to century timescales due to human perturbations.
The likelihood of crossing uncertain regional climate thresholds increases with further warming.
Integrated, multi-sectoral adaptation solutions increase adaptation effectiveness.
Inclusive and long-term planning at multiple governance scales facilitates system transitions.
Higher greenhouse gas emissions lead to greater and faster sea level rise due to increased magnitude, rate, and timing of threshold exceedances.
Extreme sea level events that were once per century in the past are projected to occur at least annually at more than half of tide gauge locations by 2100.
With increasing warming, adaptation options become more constrained and less effective.
At higher warming levels, losses and damages increase, and more human and natural systems reach adaptation limits.
Integrated, cross-cutting multi-sectoral solutions improve adaptation effectiveness.
Maladaptation can create lock-ins of vulnerability and risks, but can be avoided by long-term, flexible, multi-sectoral, inclusive planning.
Sea level rise exceeding 15 meters by 2300 cannot be ruled out under very high emissions scenarios.
Long-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions benefit many sectors and systems.
The probability of low-likelihood, high-impact climate outcomes increases with higher global warming levels.
Warming substantially above the very likely range for a scenario cannot be ruled out and would lead to greater regional climate changes.
Global mean sea level rise above the likely range could approach 2 meters by 2100 and exceed 15 meters by 2300 under very high emissions.
The effects of Solar Radiation Modification (SRM) depend on the specific method used, and sudden stopping of SRM under high CO2 emissions would cause rapid climate change.
SRM does not stop atmospheric CO2 concentrations from rising nor reduce ocean acidification if anthropogenic emissions continue.
There are large uncertainties and knowledge gaps about the potential of SRM to reduce climate risks.
Lack of robust SRM governance risks international tensions due to deployment by a limited number of states.
Projected regional impacts on fisheries and marine ecosystems depend on ocean temperature, oxygen, and primary production.
Models do not represent changes in fishing activities or some extreme climate conditions.
Projected changes in Arctic regions have low confidence due to modelling uncertainties involving multiple interacting drivers and ecosystem responses.
Heatwaves' duration and intensity are not presented here.
Heat-related health outcomes depend on location and socio-economic and other non-climatic factors.

Regions such as the Arctic and small island developing states are not considered to be at high risk due to climate change.
Climate change impacts become simpler and easier to manage with increased warming.

The portion of global land experiencing changes in seasonal precipitation is expected to decrease.
Many climate changes from past and future greenhouse gas emissions can be reversed within decades.
Ocean acidification, deoxygenation, and global sea level are expected to stabilize in the 21st century regardless of emissions.
Climate-related risks are assessed to be lower than in AR5 for the same level of warming.
Levels of risk for Reasons for Concern become lower at higher global warming levels compared to AR5.
Long-term impacts from global warming are projected to remain similar or decrease compared to current levels.
Risks, including cascading and overshoot risks, are expected to decrease with every increment of global warming.
With further warming, regions are expected to experience fewer concurrent and multiple climatic impact changes.
Hot climatic impact-drivers will decrease and cold climatic drivers will increase with global warming.
At 1.5°C warming, heavy precipitation and flooding are expected to become less frequent in Africa, Asia, North America, and Europe.
At 2°C or above, droughts in Europe, Africa, Australasia, and North America are projected to decrease.
Detectable changes in seasonal precipitation are expected to increase over global land regions.
Many changes from past and future GHG emissions are irreversible on centennial to millennial timescales.
Ocean acidification and sea level rise will continue to increase this century, dependent on future emissions.

Long-term impacts from warming will be multiple times higher than currently observed for key risks.
Risks including cascading and overshoot risks worsen with every increment of warming.
Further warming causes more regions to experience multiple concurrent climatic impact changes.
Hot climatic impact-drivers such as temperature extremes increase across all regions.
Heavy precipitation and flooding intensify and become more frequent at 1.5°C warming in many regions.
At 2°C warming or above, droughts become more frequent and severe in many regions.
Tropical cyclones, extratropical storms, aridity, and fire weather are projected to intensify with warming.
Compound heatwaves and droughts are likely to become more frequent and concurrent at multiple locations.

Embedding adaptation and mitigation in development planning might help reduce vulnerability, but its effect on ecosystem conservation is unclear.
Localities with development gaps may have challenges embedding adaptation, but some progress can be made with available resources.
Strengthening enabling conditions could help adaptation, though the timeline and depth of impact are uncertain.
Barriers might limit the deployment of mitigation and adaptation options, but some progress could be possible without removing all barriers.
Integrated, multi-sectoral solutions may increase feasibility and effectiveness of options depending on local conditions.
Delaying adaptation and mitigation actions might increase some risks but could also allow time for better solutions.
Unabated fossil fuel infrastructure contributes to emissions, but some technologies might reduce emissions in the future.
Limiting warming to 2 degrees Celsius may leave some fossil fuels unburned, though economic impacts are uncertain.
Early actions to limit fossil fuel infrastructure size could reduce stranded assets, but the exact benefits vary.
Global warming is projected to increase overall in the near term, but variability may cause fluctuations.
Climate hazards will increase in many regions, though some areas might see limited changes.
The occurrence of individual years with high global surface temperature does not necessarily mean that a long-term temperature threshold has been reached.
A large explosive volcanic eruption in the near term could temporarily reduce global surface temperature and precipitation.
Section 4 covers relevant climate adaptation and mitigation topics.
Equity and inclusion are important aspects of climate change action.
Population exposed to sea level rise is projected to increase between 2020 and 2040.
All regions face more severe or frequent compound and cascading climate risks.
Principal climate hazards expected near 1.5°C global warming are diverse and regionally variable.
Many climate system changes, including extreme events, will increase in the near term with warming.
Multiple climatic and non-climatic risks interact to cause more compounding impacts that are difficult to manage.

Continuing unsustainable development will increase exposure and vulnerability to climate hazards.
Increased heavy precipitation will increase rain-generated local flooding.
Cryosphere-related changes can cause severe consequences in most mountain regions.
Climate resilient development implements mitigation and adaptation to support sustainable development.
Diverse actors making interacting choices can advance climate resilient development and enable lower emissions and adaptation.
Diverse knowledges include cultural, Indigenous, local, and scientific knowledge.
Climatic and non-climatic shocks cause more severe impacts on pathways with lower climate resilient development.
There are limits to adaptation capacity at 1.5°C warming, with losses and damages increasing with warming increments.
Development pathways influence emissions and mitigation challenges differently across countries.
Pathways and opportunities are shaped by past actions, enabling conditions, climate risks, and development gaps.
Delayed emissions reductions reduce the number of effective adaptation options available.

Adaptation cannot prevent all losses and damages, even before reaching adaptive limits.

Risk levels depend on near-term vulnerability, exposure, socio-economic development, and adaptation.

Future exposure to climatic hazards is increasing globally due to socio-economic development and migration.

Regions and people with considerable development constraints have high vulnerability to climatic hazards.
Several risks can be moderated with adaptation.
